header.title: The Scroll of Set - August 1997
authors: Don Webb V°, High Priest of Set
Heather Lee Ayres III°, Acting Grand Master
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Modern Magical Practice

central_thesis: The Scroll of Set, August 1997, articulates the Temple of Set's philosophy of Xeper (self-evolution) as a dynamic process of individual and communal transformation, integrating practical magical workings, esoteric concepts like the Black Flame, and strategic engagement with both internal psychological states and external societal forces. It emphasizes the active role of the Initiate in shaping reality and deepening self-awareness through conscious practice and adaptation.

structure_content.summary: Details a collaborative working involving sixteen Pylons and over eighty Setians to create a 'meta-egregore' to recalibrate Pylon egregores in resonance with a deeper understanding of Xeper. Conceived during the Egyptian season of Proyet (Khoiak), it symbolizes sowing seeds of creation for future utilization as a powerful tool against stasis in the 'World of Horrors'. The transcript of this communal working is to be archived and made available to all Setians.

Explores the solitary nature of the Setian initiatory quest for 'first principles,' contrasting human 'herd' behavior with the hawk's solitary nature as a symbol of separation from the natural order. Proposes a threefold understanding of initiation (consciousness, action, skills) corresponding to the Set-animal (consciousness), Horus-animal (action), and other god-forms (skills) to achieve Xeper. This quest is posited as the 'sine qua non' of the Left-Hand Path and the Order of Horus.

structure_content.chapter_title: [4] Desire: A Fivefold Key to Transformation
structure_content.summary: Presents 'desire' as a potent force for self-transformation (Xeper), distinct from mere 'wanting.' It outlines a five-step process involving 'The Lover' (the desiring self), 'The Beloved' (the object of desire), 'The Shadow' (an invoked image of the perfect lover/projected hidden self), 'The Dæmon' (acknowledged latent aspects of self), and 'The Serpent' (the ongoing process of Remanifestation and self-recreation through a pentagramic schema).

Analyzes tradition from a Setian perspective as a means to order chaos, remanifest thought-patterns into objective reality, and deepen self-awareness. Emphasizes that for Black Magicians, tradition must serve to impose one's will on reality and be subordinate to the self. It warns against traditions practiced for their own sake, which can weaken the Initiate, and notes that predictable repetition can make one vulnerable if not balanced with rhythmic, self-serving relevance.

structure_content.chapter_title: [6] Religious Rights and the Temple of Set
structure_content.summary: Discusses the unconstitutionality of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 by the Supreme Court, and its implications for 'fringe' religious groups like the Temple of Set amidst rising Christian fundamentalism. The author expresses concern about potential religious persecution and emphasizes the Setian responsibility to create their own destinies and realities through Xeper, advocating for unity and strength.

structure_content.chapter_title: [8] All Honor to the Fires of Anat
structure_content.summary: Explores the ancient Canaanite warrior goddess Anat as a destructive, fiery neter and consort to Set/Baal, embodying 'Power and Purity'. Introduces the 'Red Flame' as a counterpart to Set's 'Black Flame,' which makes conscious self-awareness 'visible' by consuming mental clutter and stasis, allowing power to manifest freely. Includes a practical ritual example for invoking Anat to ignite and purify the Black Flame, adapting it for individual needs.

Provides various administrative and philosophical notes from the High Priest of Set. This includes the appointment of a Regional Director (Magister David d'Merlin) to manage European affairs, a clear statement of the Temple of Set's core dogma (Being and Becoming, conscious means, Temple as tool), a discussion of the Egyptian custom of Inw (gift-giving) as a magical circulation of power, and an outline of the 'MetaMind Element' (non-natural force, synchronicity, cognitive fluidity) as a key to immortality and understanding the 'quintessence of bodily experience'.

Offers reviews of media (film, music, audiobooks) with occult or Left-Hand Path relevance. Highlights 'Dangerous Liaisons' as an illustration of LBM, Laibach's music for its use of power symbols and connection to Xeper/Remanifestation, 'Interview With The Vampire' soundtrack as working music, and Clark Ashton Smith's readings for esoteric completists. These are presented as resources for Setian practice and understanding.

structure_content.chapter_title: [11] "Is That Authorized Aboard Ship?" The Setian at Sea
structure_content.summary: Provides a detailed, humorous, yet practical guide for Setians to perform rituals in the highly restrictive environment of a U.S. Naval vessel. It outlines adaptations for chamber preparation (shower/toilet stall), dress, bell usage (avoiding ship's bells), lighting (Black Flashlight), makeshift implements, elemental summoning (aquatic focus), and invocation. The central invocation focuses on controlling one's will and manifesting desire despite limitations.

structure_content.chapter_title: [12] Opening Night: The Theatre as Magic
structure_content.summary: Argues for the integral role of psychodrama and theatrical techniques in group magical workings, enhancing emotional projection and achieving 'willing suspension of disbelief.' Discusses the James-Lange and Stanislavski ('The Method' / 'magic 'if'') acting techniques, advocating for the latter's application in Greater Black Magic to convey emotions effectively and lead participants in ritual, recognizing magic's inherent theatrical elements.

Presents a detailed esoteric analysis of Aleister Crowley's *Liber AL vel Legis* verse #III-72, specifically 'I am the Lord of the Double Wand of Power; the Force of Coph Nia.' The author speculates 'Double Wand of Power' might refer to 'Double Wind of Power' (DNA) and 'Coph Nia' as a hieroglyphic variant of Xeper, drawing parallels with HarWer and spiral force concepts. It critiques previous commentaries, asserting an informed authority through personal bond with Set.

structure_content.chapter_title: [14] Close Encounters of the Skeptical Kind
structure_content.summary: Reports on a lecture by a skeptic on UFOs and paranormal phenomena, highlighting how observers and investigators can be deceived by misinterpreted natural events or intentional hoaxes. The author connects this to the dangers of obscuring objective and subjective truth, particularly in light of events like the Heaven's Gate suicide, emphasizing the need for Setians to maintain clear discernment and avoid being fooled by 'stage magic' in occult contexts.

Describes the Order of Uart (formerly Order of the Python), dedicated to art and magic within the Temple of Set. Its foundation is 'Nine Perceptions of Heka-An,' which posit art as a valid expression, record of initiation, magical link, and means to understand Set. The Order's structure includes nine Neter Guilds and individual Temenos/studios. Members are expected to produce artifacts, affect the objective universe through art, reflect their evolving Set-nature, and participate in the Order's Xeper.

Details the creation of a 'Stele of Empathy' in response to a challenge to create an object stemming from emotions rather than intellect. The author describes a process of spontaneous emotional flow leading to a collage of digital images. The key insight is the realization that logical critique would have undermined the original emotional purity and intent of the creation, emphasizing the value of emotionally-driven artistic expression in personal transformation.

key_concepts.definition: The core philosophy of the Temple of Set, denoting self-evolution, self-creation, and active transformation of the individual's consciousness and being. It is a dynamic and ongoing process.

The conscious self-awareness or isolate intelligence within an individual, considered the Gift of Set. It is an invisible core of being, the source from which theories and interpretations are generated, and a point of unique, individualized existence.

A complementary force to the Black Flame, specifically associated with the goddess Anat. It represents a blazing consciousness that knows and reveals itself, embodying power and purity, with the capacity to consume stasis and purify the Black Flame, rendering it visible and active.

A communal energetic construct or thought-form, created through a collective working (e.g., Xepera Mundi). It serves as a tool for Setians to dispel stasis, claim realms of existence, and strengthen the collective spiritual endeavors of the Pylons within the Temple of Set.

The fundamental, universal truths that are the ultimate subject of the initiatory quest within the Left-Hand Path. This quest is inherently solitary, requiring the individual to discover these underlying realities for themselves.

A profound hunger, need, or passion that acts as a powerful catalyst for self-transformation (Xeper). It is analyzed through five 'players': The Lover (the desiring self), The Beloved (the object of desire), The Shadow (the invoked ideal image of the perfect lover), The Dæmon (projected hidden aspects of the self), and The Serpent (the process of remanifestation and self-recreation.

A framework for bringing order to chaos, remanifesting thought-patterns into objective reality, and influencing the universe. For Black Magicians, tradition must be consciously applied and subordinate to the self, serving the purpose of imposing one's will, rather than being followed for its own sake.

An ancient Egyptian concept denoting the magical and religious circulation of wealth, power, or spiritual essence through the act of giving and receiving gifts. It is explicitly linked to the Black Flame as Set's ultimate gift to humanity.

A non-natural force or substance that informs the psyche, influencing phenomena like synchronicity and cognitive fluidity. It is considered the 'quintessence of bodily experience' and is linked to self-immortalization, influencing the interaction between the Black Flame and historical processes.

The application of psychodrama and theatrical techniques (e.g., Stanislavski Method, 'magic 'if'') to enhance the efficacy of group magical workings. It involves using emotional projection and practiced stagecraft to stir participants, direct collective will, and achieve a 'willing suspension of disbelief' necessary for manifesting magical intent.

An Egyptian term meaning 'the artists' quarter' or 'the well of the flame in the great oasis.' It refers to an Order within the Temple of Set dedicated to the exploration of art and magic, viewing artistic creation as a primary means of Xeper and gaining knowledge of Set, guided by 'Nine Perceptions of Heka-An'.

practical_system.description: The 'Scroll of Set - August 1997' outlines a practical system of self-initiated transformation (Xeper) within the Temple of Set framework. It integrates solitary philosophical quests with communal magical workings, emphasizing the conscious application of esoteric principles. The system encourages the Initiate to adapt magical practices to their unique circumstances, whether through structured rituals, artistic creation, or psychological introspection. It provides methodologies for cultivating self-awareness (Black Flame), channeling desire for change, engaging with tradition strategically, and leveraging external influences (e.g., media, societal issues) for personal and collective magical ends. The overarching aim is to empower the individual to actively shape their reality, deepen their understanding of self and Set, and contribute to the evolution of the Order.
tools: Black Flame (conceptual framework for isolate self-consciousness)
Red Flame (as an active force of purification and manifestation)
Desire (as a fivefold analytical and operative key for transformation)
Tradition (as a adaptable framework for manifesting will, subordinate to the individual)
Theatrical Techniques (psychodrama, Stanislavski Method, 'magic 'if'', emotional projection for group workings)
Ritual Implements (e.g., bells, chalice, knife/Gillette Sensor, Black Flashlight/oil lamp, Sterno, objects for burning)
MetaMind Element (for analyzing synchronicity and non-natural forces)
Artistic Mediums (visual art, performance art, writing, music, etc., used for Xeper)
rituals: The Xepera Mundi Working (communal egregor recalibration and strengthening)
Anat Invocation ('Red Flame' ritual for purifying and igniting the Black Flame, involving specific offerings and spoken words)
Setian ritual aboard a ship (adaptations for confined and restrictive environments, including specific instructions for preparation, invocation, and elemental summoning)
Artistic Creation as a Magical Act (within the Order of Uart, focusing on art as a record of initiation, a magical link, and a means to reveal the mind of Set)
Inw (Gift-giving) as a magical circulation of power and spiritual essence

relevant_quotes.text: The Xepera Mundi now stands in being as a tool for those Pylons of the Temple of Set, both present and future, to utilize as they move forth into the World of Horrors.

As Xeper has evolved an octave to deeper levels of meaning and qualification, so did it stand to reason that the Pylons of the Temple of Set, in achieving resonance with that octave, could further evolve through the Word that is the cornerstone of who and what we are as a Temple.
This solitary quest for first principles is the sine qua non of the Left-Hand Path [and the Order of Horus].
Desire is something greater than simply 'wanting'; it implies a hunger, a need, a passion.
The dæmonic self represents those aspects of self which we have always been afraid to acknowledge and actualize...
Tradition is a means of Remanifesting our thought-patterns into objective reality.

Traditions practiced by Black Magicians are for the purpose of imposing one's will on reality. Tradition as an act of GBM systematically alters the patterns of reality to the will of the Magician and his SU, aiding him in his Essent Into Essence.
As we Setians can create our own luck, we can create our own destinies. Part of the gift and the responsibility of Xeper is the creation of the world and the reality in which we want to live.
Power and Purity define the Fires of Anat, a blazing Red Flame that is the contrast, counterpart, and consort to the Black Flame of Set.
Anat's gift is the complement of Set's Gift. Anat's power and purity allow us to ignite the Black Flame and render it visible.

The purpose of the Temple is not to strip you bare of the many influences you may have had on your way here. The Temple hopes only to provide you with an opportunity for clarity - a methodology to sort out your life-experiences so that you know what you can use and how you can use it for our own self-development.
Magic always involves some elements of theatre, and it benefits immensely from an intelligent and trained application thereof.
Through the act of creation the mind of Set can begin to be known.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document offers a unique snapshot of the Temple of Set's internal discourse and practical application of its philosophy in 1997. It is highly relevant for understanding the evolution of modern Left-Hand Path esotericism, demonstrating how a structured magical order encourages individual autonomy (Xeper) while fostering communal workings and addressing external challenges (e.g., religious freedom, adapting rituals to modern constraints). The technical discussions on concepts like the Black Flame, MetaMind, and the integration of diverse methodologies (e.g., theatrical techniques, artistic creation) showcase a sophisticated and adaptive magical system. It provides invaluable primary source material for researchers studying contemporary occultism and the Temple of Set's distinct contributions to Western Esotericism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is Initiates and prospective members of the Temple of Set. Academics and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Left-Hand Path magic, and Chaos Magic will find it valuable for its deep philosophical and practical insights. Scholars of new religious movements, cultural studies, and modern occult history would also benefit from its contextualization of the Temple's activities and thought in the late 20th century.
